reviewText: Nobody - I MEAN NO ONE has the soul of Hendrix.  All these "Dime a Dozen" songs of today, Nobody could play the guitar like he could.  Jimi's a Monster when he played. That is why I play the keyboard now!...and when he sets his guitar on fire, Mayhem erupted!!

reviewText: First although this is BR, there is only so much that can be done with the poor video quality from the sixties. That said this is the best concert footage I've seen of Jimi. I have this on regular DVD as well as BR. Get the BR!If you're too young to remember the Hendrix sensation, get this DVD and you will understand! Absolutely awesome!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I wish there were more quality documents to this amazing time, but they are unfortunately few and far between.  Capturing history on film is a rare thing, and capturing it with incredible sound is even more so.  This is without a doubt a must see for any Hendrix fan, diehard or casual.  The performance is phenomenal, and the picture and sound - especially the sound, are excellent.  The film -especially the interviews - is really illuminating for someone like myself who had heard the performance on CD for years, but had not actually seen the entire performance or knew the story behind the Festival.  Again, a really amazing document captured here.  I don't believe the entire Festival is available yet on BluRay, but when it is I'd love to have it.  Of course it might seem anticlimactic since it appears that only a handful of performances could even light a candle to Hendrix.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was very disappointed when I watched this Blu Ray version of Jimi's historic concert at Monterey.  I had already purchased the regular DVD version of this feature so I hoped the Blu Ray version would surpass that. I was very mistaken.  Correct me if I'm wrong but I thought Blu Ray technology equals true HD which, if I'm not mistaken, should be in wide-screen format, right?  Well, Jimi's whole Monterey performance is presented here with those annoying black-bars and either side of my HD wide-screen tv. Trust me, it's not the settings on my tv.  It's simply the way that the film is presented on this "blu ray" disc.  A total rip-off.  Am I missing something here?  If you have the DVD version already, save your money because the Blu Ray version is exactly the same presentation.
summary: Blu Ray exactly like DVD version

reviewText: If a film is shot in Full Frame originally, then it should not be cropped for widescreen.BluRay = High resolutionBluRay not = Widescreen.They even squawked the Wizard of Oz was not in widescreen."But's it noooooot in Wiiiidescreen"

reviewText: i have the criterion dvd and this blu-ray isnt much different in the video department. audiowise they are both very sweet and hard to choose... but this version has the extra footage as a bonus special featute.. it was fun seeing the show again froma different viewpoint.the concert is edited slightly different and is mostly the same but i found it refreshing. also included is all the avialble footage of purple haze. can you see me is still missing.menus are very cool with jimis burning guitar. on criterion you have to switch between otis and hendrix and the menu looks like recycled tree paper. you also have to but the 3 disc version to get some monterey history.. this blu-ray has a small doc on monterey if your interested then you can get criterion version of that.
Title: N/A

reviewText: (Released 10.16.07) I had to hunt around for a copy of this on its release date but it was well worth it. It includes the original footage with additional camera angles and some documentaries which are also included. Also an added bonus is footage from Chelmsford from February of 1967. The newly released CD doesn't really add anything new but this DVD has enough bonus material to make it worthwhile.
